   Assessment and Plan
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION

 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have SBP as well as a
   possibilty of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however now hematocrit is ~21, will plan to transfuse.
   Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger), hyponatremia,
   hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but also
   concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency and cortisol is
   currently pending.
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60
   - Antibiotics as below
   - Monitor CVP (goal>8) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - F/u cortisol level, consider [**Last Name (un) **] stim test in am;  Cortsol: 29.5
   - BCx consistent with clostridium or bacillus
   - Consult ID regarding appropriate antibiotic regimen
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significantl left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn
   - Add Clindamycin
   - D/C Cipro
   - ID Consult re: abx regimen
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - Albumin 1.5g/kg on day 1 (125g) and 1g/kg (75) on day 3
   .
   Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given hypotension,
   concern for developing respiratory failure given tachypnea. ABG in MICU
   indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings.
   - Decrease RR to 24, given most recent ABG.  Maintain FiO2 at 60% for
   now.
   - ABG and lactate [**Hospital1 **]
   - Maintain on ventilator for now given sepsis, plan for EGD.
   - Sedation with Fentanyl and Midazolam gtt
   .
   Dyspnea: The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.
   - Follow up rapid influenza
   - f/u sputum culture
   - ABGs as above
   - Continue ventilator support
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and is
   currently 21. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and has
   frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced.
   - GI/liver to do EGD to evaluate for UGIB cause: no bleeding
   - Was transfused 2u pRBC this morning, crossmatch 4u pRBCs.  Transfuse
   as needed for falling Hct.
   - Check hemolysis labs (LDH is elevated at baseline, bili elevated,
   fractionate bili, send hapto) and DIC labs (fibrinogen, d dimer)
   - pantoprazole bolus and gtt, octreotide gtt for likely variceal
   bleeding:
 d/c now as no bleeding
   - Continue IV PPI
   - [**Hospital1 **] hematocrit and lytes11
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a normal anion
   gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect acidosis is
   secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP.  s/p 2
   units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**].
   - Add-on serum EtOH
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart if post EGD if PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   currently improving.
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 77, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.
   - Trend plts
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   - F/u hemolysis labs
   .
   FEN: Bolus IVF prn, replete electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   .
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   .
   Communication: Patient's GF and son
   Contact Info:
   Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]
   cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**]

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. He has been diagnosed with sepsis, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), respiratory failure, anemia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatitis C cirrhosis, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and epistaxis. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 142/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 28 breaths per minute, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 60%. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.7 thousand/mm3, elevated lactate levels at 5.9 mmol/L, hyponatremia with a sodium level of 117 mEq/L, hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 6.1 mEq/L, and hypoglycemia with a glucose level of 69 mg/dL. His liver function tests are abnormal with elevated bilirubin levels and elevated liver enzymes

   - pantoprazole bolus and gtt, octreotide gtt for likely variceal

 d/c now as no bleeding, start IV PPI
   - q4h hematocrit
   .

   gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect acidosis is
   secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - transfuse 2u pRBC's now
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**].
   - Add-on serum EtOH
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart if post EGD if PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 77, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.
   - Trend plts
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   - F/u hemolysis labs
   .
   FEN: Bolus IVF prn, replete electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He presented with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possibly community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient's current condition includes sepsis without organ dysfunction, anemia (chronic and acute due to blood loss), thrombocytopenia (chronic), cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis other, metabolic acidosis, respiratory failure, and dyspnea. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 142/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is not provided.

The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation with the following settings: FiO2 60%, PEEP 8 cmH2O, Vt set at 500 mL, RR set at 28 breaths per minute, plateau pressure of 21 cmH2O, and compliance of 43.1 mL/cmH2O. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.31, PaCO2 of 19 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 122, and base excess of -10.5 mEq/L.

The patient's laboratory results include white blood cell count of 16.7 K/uL, hematocrit of 21.5%, platelet count of 77 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 28 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL, sodium of 143 mg/dL, potassium of 6.1 mEq/L, chloride of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate of 15 mEq/L, blood glucose of 143 mg/dL, and liver enzymes (ALT and AST) elevated. The patient's coagulation profile shows a prothrombin time (PT) of 25.5 seconds, partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 53.9 seconds, and international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.5.

The patient's urinalysis shows 16.7 K/uL of white blood cells, 87% neutrophils, and 33% bands. The patient's ascitic fluid analysis shows 17,000 WBCs per mm³ with 87% neutrophils and a significant left shift on the differential.

The patient's imaging studies include a chest X-ray (CXR) which initially raised concern for right lower lobe infiltrate, but is now interpreted as normal. The patient's abdominal ultrasound (US) shows no free fluid or organ dysfunction.

The patient's medical history includes hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. The patient has a history of chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease and has recently experienced an acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer.

The patient's immediate concerns include sepsis secondary to SBP and possible CAP, respiratory failure, metabolic acidosis, and anemia. The patient requires aggressive management with broad-spectrum antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, vasopressors, and blood transfusions as needed. The patient should be closely monitored for organ dysfunction and complications of his underlying liver disease.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening sepsis leading to septic shock, development of organ dysfunction (such as acute kidney injury or hepatic encephalopathy), further gastrointestinal bleeding, and respiratory distress requiring tracheostomy or changes in ventilator settings. The patient's prognosis is guarded due to his underlying liver disease and the severity of his current condition.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual with septic shock, respiratory failure, and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been receiving multiple antibiotics for the suspected infection. The patient's vital signs indicate hypotension and altered oxygenation. Laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, acute kidney injury, and metabolic acidosis. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Organ dysfunction: The patient is at risk of developing organ dysfunction due to septic shock and acute kidney injury.
2. Respiratory complications: Mechanical ventilation may lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or barotrauma.
3. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to further organ perfusion issues.
4. Infection progression: Despite antibiotic therapy, there is a risk of ongoing infection spread and resistance.
5. Liver failure: Acute on chronic liver failure may progress, leading to hepatic encephalopathy or coagulopathy.
6. Bleeding complications: Thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding events, such as oropharyngeal hemorrhage.
7. Metabolic imbalances: Acidosis and electrolyte abnormalities need careful management to prevent further complications.
8. Renal replacement therapy: The patient may require dialysis due to acute renal failure and hyperkalemia.

   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however now hematocrit is ~21, will plan to transfuse.
   Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger), hyponatremia,
   hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but also
   concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency and cortisol is
   currently pending.
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression; (d/c vasopressin
   first as tolerated)

   - Antibiotics as below

   - BCx consistent with clostridium perfringens

   Vanc/Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin
   - hold CT abdomen given clinical improvement
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significantl left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin

   - f/u GI/Liver recs

   .

   concern for developing respiratory failure given tachypnea. ABG in MICU
   indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings.
   - Maintain FiO2 at 60% for now, then decrease to 50% as tolerated
   - Decrease RR

   - Maintain on ventilator for now given sepsis, plan for EGD.
   - Sedation with Fentanyl and Midazolam gtt
   .
   Dyspnea: The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to

   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia

d now as no bleeding

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently in the ICU, intubated, and on mechanical ventilation. He has sepsis likely secondary to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possibly due to pneumonia. He is also experiencing respiratory failure, anemia, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to SBP and possibly pneumonia. It is important to continue aggressive management with appropriate antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, and hemodynamic support.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised, and he is currently on mechanical ventilation. Monitoring ABGs, maintaining adequate oxygenation, and weaning off the ventilator as tolerated will be crucial.
3. Anemia: The patient has chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease and superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer. Blood transfusions may be necessary to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and found to have spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possible community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient has sepsis, hypothermia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia, and concerns for adrenal insufficiency. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a low platelet count and thrombocytopenia. The patient also has anemia, likely secondary to chronic liver disease and acute blood loss. There is evidence of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP. The patient's MELD score on admission was 27, indicating advanced liver disease. He also has acute renal failure, possibly secondary to sepsis. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Organ dysfunction and failure due to sepsis and multi-organ involvement.
2. Progression of liver disease and potential development of hepatic encephalopathy.
3. Development of respiratory failure and need for prolonged ventilatory support.
4. Further deterioration of renal function and progression to chronic renal failure.
5. Hemorrhagic complications due to thrombocytopenia and potential re-bleeding from var

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis presenting with peritonitis due to Clostridium perfringens. He is currently in the ICU and has several medical complications.

1. Septic Shock/GPRs: The patient is still on two pressors (vasopressin and norepinephrine) but his lactate levels have decreased, indicating improvement. Vasopressin will be discontinued.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's FiO2 will be attempted to be weaned.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have improved.

4. Oropharyngeal hemorrhage: The ENT will be consulted about discontinuing cisatracurium and removal of packing.

Other ongoing issues mentioned in the ICU team's note are also being managed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Organ dysfunction: The patient is at risk for further organ dysfunction, particularly in the context of sepsis and acute renal failure.

2. Infection: Despite receiving appropriate antibiotics, there is a risk of developing new infections due to the immunocompromised state caused by chronic liver disease and critical illness.

3. Bleeding: Given the patient's coagulopathy and ongoing use of anticoagulants, there is a risk of bleeding complications.

4. Respiratory distress: Weaning off mechanical ventilation may be challenging, and the patient

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Active issues
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
   - d/c cisatracurium
   - Continuing Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc
   - Monitor CVP (goal>8; ideal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; however,
   will hold off on steroids for now.
   - BCx consistent with clostridium perfringens
   - hold CT abdomen given clinical improvement
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin.
   - Continue Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - Albumin 1.5g/kg on day 1 (125g) and 1g/kg (75) on day 3 ([**12-17**]).
   - Hepatobiliary sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his
   WBC is still very high, he may need to be explored.
   - General surgery c/s for possible exploration, note pending
   .
   Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given hypotension,
   concern for developing respiratory failure given tachypnea. ABG in MICU
   indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings.
   - Maintain FiO2 at 60% for now, then decrease to 50% as tolerated
   - Decrease RR
   - ABG and lactate [**Hospital1 **] (lactate down-trending now)
   - Maintain on ventilator for now given sepsis.
   - Sedation with Fentanyl and Midazolam gtt
   .
   Dyspnea: The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.
   - f/u sputum culture
   - ABGs as above
   - Continue ventilator support
   - Attempt to decrease FiO2 as aobe.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs; packing removed yesterday. Remainder of packing to be
   removed tomorrow ([**12-18**]).
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.
   - Pt was on pantoprazole bolus and octreotide gtt for likely variceal
   bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT stable.
   - Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart when PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.
   - Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many small
   platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the same
   time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a normal anion
   gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect acidosis is
   secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP.  s/p 2
   units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   - Now resolved.
   .
   FEN: Bolus IVF prn, replete electrolytes

The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He presented with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), respiratory failure, epistaxis, anemia, hepatitis C cirrhosis, and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C (97.5°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 109/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 60% and a RR of 16 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 16.7 K/uL, elevated neutrophils in ascitic fluid, and a left shift on CBC with diff. The patient also has elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, as well as elevated bilirubin levels. The patient's platelet count is 34 K/uL, indicating thrombocytopenia.

The patient's imaging studies reveal hazy appearance of the abdomen consistent with ascites, gas-filled transverse colon with no evidence of perforation or free air, and increased engorgement of pulmonary vessels with generalized haziness bil

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however now hematocrit is ~21, will plan to transfuse.
   Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger), hyponatremia,
   hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but also
   concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency and cortisol is
   currently pending.
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
   - d/c cisatracurium
   - Antibiotics as below
   - Monitor CVP (goal>8; ideal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - repeat AM cortisol stim test today
   - BCx consistent with clostridium perfringens
   - F/u ID consult re: antibiotic regimen, currently on:
   Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin
   - hold CT abdomen given clinical improvement
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin.
   - Continue Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin
   -  ID Consult: continue zosyn, clinda, mica, dc vanc
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - Albumin 1.5g/kg on day 1 (125g) and 1g/kg (75) on day 3
   - Hepatobiliary sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his
   WBC is still very high, he may need to be explored.
   .
   Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given hypotension,
   concern for developing respiratory failure given tachypnea. ABG in MICU
   indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings.
   - Maintain FiO2 at 60% for now, then decrease to 50% as tolerated
   - Decrease RR
   - ABG and lactate [**Hospital1 **] (lactate downtrending now)
   - Maintain on ventilator for now given sepsis, plan for EGD.
   - Sedation with Fentanyl and Midazolam gtt
   .
   Dyspnea: The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.
   - f/u sputum culture
   - ABGs as above
   - Continue ventilator support
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs; packing removed yesterday. Remainder of packing to be
   removed tomorrow.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and is
   currently 21. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and has
   frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced.
   - GI/liver to do EGD to evaluate for UGIB cause: no bleeding
   - Was transfused 2u pRBC this morning, crossmatch 4u pRBCs.  Transfuse
   as needed for falling Hct.
   - pantoprazole bolus and gtt, octreotide gtt for likely variceal
   bleeding: d/c
d now as no bleeding
   - Continue IV PPI
   - Daily coags and CBC
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a normal anion
   gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect acidosis is
   secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP.  s/p 2
   units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   - consider lasix in PM to help UO
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**].
   - Add-on serum EtOH - negative
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart if post EGD if PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   FEN: Bolus IVF prn, replete electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Summary of Progress Note:
- ENT removed packing from the patient's nose, leaving the remainder in place until tomorrow.
- The patient underwent a stimulus test for adrenal insufficiency, which showed improvement in heart rate after administration of diltiazem.
- Renal function is improving, as indicated by the decreasing lactate levels.
- Hepatology recommendations include performing a paracentesis and re-tapping the patient due to persistent high WBC count in ascitic fluid.
- The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with ventilator support, FiO2 at 60%, and a planned EGD to evaluate for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) cause.
- The patient's anemia is suspected to be chronic macrocytic due to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer.
- Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis is suspected secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
- Hepatitis C cirrhosis is present, with a MELD score of 27 and a discriminate

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient is currently diagnosed with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition caused by a widespread infection. If left untreated or not managed properly, it can lead to organ dysfunction and potentially be fatal.

2. Peritonitis: The patient has signs of peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum, the lining of the abdomen. If not treated promptly, it can progress to a severe infection called spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and lead to organ dysfunction.

3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), which increases the risk of bleeding complications. This can be a result of sepsis or other underlying conditions.

4. Anemia: The patient has chronic and acute anemia, which may be due to blood loss or other causes. Anemia can compromise oxygen delivery to tissues and may require treatment.

5. Liver cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis of the liver, which is a chronic condition characterized by scarring of the liver tissue. This can lead to complications such as portal hypertension, ascites, and increased risk of infections.

6. Hepatitis: The patient also has hepatitis, which is inflammation of the liver. If not properly managed, it can further damage the liver and lead to complications like hepatic enceph

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with HCV cirrhosis admitted to the ICU for peritonitis due to Clostridium perfringens. The patient's chief complaints include respiratory failure, septic shock, and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

The patient is currently sedated and unable to provide a history. Allergies are not known. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Micafungin, Clindamycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn).

The patient is being mechanically ventilated with a Vt set at 500 mL, RR set at 16 breaths per minute, PEEP at 10 cmH2O, FiO2 at 60%, and SpO2 of 95%. ABG results indicate a pH of 7.50, PaCO2 of 33 mmHg, HCO3 of 113 mEq/L, and SaO2 of 95%.

Physical examination reveals no acute distress, normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat, normal heart sounds, symmetric chest expansion with clear breath sounds, non-tender and distended abdomen, 1+ edema in both lower extremities, warm skin, and no neurologic assessment due to sedation.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with WBC count ranging from 16.7 to 13.6 K/uL,

1. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possibly pneumonia. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and pressors to support blood pressure.

2. Peritonitis: The patient has signs consistent with SBP, including abdominal pain, prominent neutrophilia in ascitic fluid, and a significant left shift on complete blood count (CBC) with differential. He will be treated with ciprofloxacin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and vancomycin.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated in the emergency department due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure. His ABG indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings. FiO2 will be maintained at 60% for now, then decreased to 50% as tolerated. RR will be decreased, and ABG and lactate levels will be monitored.

   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia

   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB

   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c

   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and was found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg and a heart rate of 86 bpm. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow ventilation mode, set tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%. The patient's oxygen saturation is 96%. 

The patient has several medical complications, including sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), anemia, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis, metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure, and epistaxis. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, decreased platelet count, decreased hemoglobin, and decreased potassium levels. 

The patient's imaging studies reveal a minimally increased right lower lobe opacity on chest X-ray and ascites with marked pleat on abdominal ultrasound.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is unable to maintain a FIO2 below 0.6, indicating severe respiratory distress. This may progress to complete respiratory failure if not adequately supported.

3. Oropharyngeal hemorrhage: The patient experienced an oropharyngeal bleed, which has been packed. If the bleeding recurs or the packing is unsuccessful, this could result in significant airway compromise.

4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which increases the risk of bleeding complications, especially given the recent oropharyngeal hemorrhage.

He presented with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated for sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), anemia, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 37.3°C (99.2°F)
- Heart rate: 77 bpm
- Blood pressure: 95/50 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 96%
- Central venous pressure (CVP): 17 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:
- White blood cell count: 12.4 K/uL
- Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
- Platelet count: 30 K/uL
- Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
- Blood glucose: 86 mg/dL
- Sodium: 27 mEq/L
- Potassium: 3.8 mEq/L
- Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Consider Lasix diuresis tomorrow for volume overload, hold for now
   given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan on [**12-17**] so want to protect
   kidneys
   - Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, keep PEEP steady as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs this PEEP level.
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Change from fentanyl and midazolam (concern with ARF that these
   medications are going to not be cleared for a while and may potentiate
   AMS as well as ileus); change to propofol
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - Give FFP prior to packing removal today ([**12-18**]) by ENT
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart when PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   - Now resolved.
   - s/p IV contrast dye load on [**12-17**], watch Cr and hold on diuresis.
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)

   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis presenting with peritonitis caused by C. perfringens. He is currently experiencing septic shock and respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.2 C (98.9 F), heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 108/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history.

The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate set at 16 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 60%. His ABG results show a pH of 7.47, PaCO2 of 41 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 178, and ventilation rate (Ve) of 7.5 L/min.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, normocephalic head, clear breath sounds, symmetric chest expansion, distended abdomen, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Neurologic examination shows the patient to be non-attentive, not following simple commands, and unresponsive to stimulation, with no assessed movement or tone.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, try to increase PEEP as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs a lot of PEEP.
   - Place esophageal balloon
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off x 24 hours on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility.
   - F/u renal/hepatology recs.
   - will give IV albumin 1g/kg.
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Restart lactulose today.  Titrate to 3 BMs daily.
   - Can add back Rifaxamin if no improvement with lactulose alone.
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - Restarting lactulose today
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and found to have peritonitis and a possible case of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He is also on multiple pressors to support his blood pressure. The patient's condition is complicated by sepsis, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), acute renal failure, altered mental status, epistaxis, anemia, and hepatitis C cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if there is a progression of pneumonia or if the mechanical ventilation settings need to be adjusted.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can lead to further organ dysfunction and failure if not adequately managed.
3. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): SBP can recur, leading to worsening abdominal pain and potentially causing additional complications.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function may deteriorate if not appropriately managed, leading to an accumulation of waste products and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, affecting his ability to communicate and interact with healthcare providers.
6. Epistaxis: The

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, try to increase PEEP as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs a lot of PEEP.
   - Place esophageal balloon
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off x 24 hours on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility.
   - F/u renal/hepatology recs.
   - will give IV albumin 1g/kg.
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Restart lactulose today.  Titrate to 3 BMs daily.
   - Can add back Rifaxamin if no improvement with lactulose alone.
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - Restarting lactulose today
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of CAP (Community-Acquired Pneumonia). The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), acute renal failure (ARF), altered mental status, epistaxis, anemia, hepatitis C cirrhosis, and thrombocytopenia. 

The patient's respiratory status is critical, as indicated by the need for mechanical ventilation and the presence of fluid overload and CHF (Congestive Heart Failure) on chest X-ray. The patient also has evidence of volume overload, as suggested by elevated central venous pressure (CVP) and edema. 

The patient's renal function is impaired, with rising creatinine levels over the past few days. This could be due to aggressive diuresis and IV contrast load for a CT abdomen. However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility.

The patient has altered mental status, which may be attributed to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy, given the patient's severe liver disease and rising bilirubin levels. 

Additionally, the patient has anemia, likely secondary to chronic macrocytic anemia due to liver disease, with acute

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Attempt to wean Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression
   dc
   - Start Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Continue Octreotide
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Wean [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - IVF 1L D5W today for free water
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Re-start Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently intubated due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure.

The patient's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was 21 on admission. He is guaiac positive on exam in the ED, and had frank blood in NGT. There is suspicion of acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No bleeding source was found during an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). 

The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure, possibly due to aggressive diuresis in the last several days and IV contrast load for a CT abdomen. However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given the administration of Midodrine, Octreotide, and Albumin.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy, given his severe liver disease and rising bilirubin levels. 

The patient has a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis with a MELD score of 27 on admission. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, and he is jaundiced.

The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease. He has chronic epistaxis, and there are no schistocytes on smear to indicate hemolysis.

The patient's non-anion gap metabolic acidosis has resolved, but he still has lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP. He received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) transfusion.

The patient's fluid balance shows a positive balance of 559 mL over the past 24 hours, indicating fluid overload. He also has evidence of volume overload and congestive heart failure (CHF) given edema, CXR consistent with fluid overload, and elevated central venous pressure (CVP).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hepatorenal syndrome: Given the patient's liver disease and recent administration of Midodrine and Octreotide, hepatorenal syndrome should be considered as a possible cause of the acute renal failure.

2. Chronic liver disease complications: The patient's history of hepatitis C cirrhosis puts him at risk for complications such as hepatic encephalopathy, esophageal varices bleeding, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

3. Sepsis: The patient's presentation with fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status suggests sepsis, likely secondary to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) or pneumonia.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is critically ill with a chief complaint of C. perfringens peritonitis, septic shock, and respiratory failure. The patient is sedated and unable to provide history. They have been receiving multiple antibiotics, including Clindamycin, Micafungin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient is mechanically ventilated and has an endotracheal tube in place. They are receiving norepinephrine and octreotide infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they have a distended abdomen and bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory results show anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's condition is complicated by respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, chronic anemia, acute blood loss anemia, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis, metabolic acidosis, and other comorbidities. The patient is being closely monitored in the ICU with appropriate prophylactic measures in place.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis admitted to the ICU with peritonitis caused by Clostridium perfringens. The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, chronic anemia, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis, metabolic acidosis, and acute renal failure.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/55 mmHg to 156/81 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate set at 16 breaths per minute, PEEP of 15 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values show a pH of 7.43, PaCO2 of 46 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 196.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 10.5 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) level of 8.1 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) of 38 K/uL, blood glucose level of 86 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) level of 1.2 mg/dL, total bilirubin (TBili) level of 31 mg/dL, lactate level of 2.2 mmol/L, D-dimer level of 4697 ng/mL, and elevated liver enzymes such as alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST).

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, normal cardiovascular findings, symmetric chest expansion with clear breath sounds, edema in both lower extremities, and warm skin. Neurologically, the patient is unresponsive and does not follow simple commands.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of various medical complications. Potential complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, septic shock, acute kidney injury, hepatic encephalopathy, gastrointestinal bleeding, and coagulopathy.
