   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt
   - Continue Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Attempt to wean Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression
   dc
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Wean [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - IVF 1L D5W today for free water
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Re-start Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots

The patient has been treated with various antibiotics, pressors, and other medications. The patient remains in the ICU pending clinical improvement.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's difficulty in breathing and low oxygen saturation indicate respiratory failure. Maintaining him on mechanical ventilation and adjusting the ventilator settings as needed is crucial.
3. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The presence of abdominal pain, neutrophilia in ascitic fluid, and significant left-shift on CBC with diff are consistent with SBP. Continued treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics is necessary.
4. Anemia: The patient has both chronic and acute anemia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt
   - Continue Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Pressors off as of [**12-20**]
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Weaned [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.  D/C
ed Hydrocort [**12-21**].
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; consider
   Metoclopramide/Reglan if patient begins having bowel sounds to increase
   gastric motility and improve abdominal distension
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.  Attempt to decrease PEEP from 15 to 12 given patient
   tolerated weaning of FIO2.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved
   UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Given pt has nl sodium, hold on IVF today
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes.
   Initiate TPN today and consult nutrition.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), acute anemia secondary to blood loss, chronic thrombocytopenia, liver cirrhosis, and altered mental status. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 113/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40% and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cmH2O. 

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count (WBC) of 17,000/mm3, elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT), hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia, elevated lactate levels, and elevated bilirubin levels. The patient's creatinine level has been rising again, indicating possible acute renal

   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of CAP. He has respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and sepsis without organ dysfunction. He also has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), chronic anemia, thrombocytopenia, altered mental status, and hepatitis C cirrhosis. The patient's condition remains critical, and he is currently in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a concern for pneumonia or influenza, as well as fluid overload and congestive heart failure (CHF) due to elevated CVP and edema.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been rising again, indicating acute renal failure. This may be due to aggressive diuresis and IV contrast load for CT abdomen. Hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility.

3. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis without organ dysfunction, which is likely secondary to SBP and possibly pneumonia. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

4. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The patient has signs consistent with SBP, including abdominal pain, high neutroph

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt
   - Continue Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Pressors off as of [**12-20**]
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Weaned [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.  D/C
ed Hydrocort [**12-21**].
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; consider
   Metoclopramide/Reglan if patient begins having bowel sounds to increase
   gastric motility and improve abdominal distension
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.  Attempt to decrease PEEP from 15 to 12 given patient
   tolerated weaning of FIO2.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved
   UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Given pt has nl sodium, hold on IVF today
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes.
   Initiate TPN today and consult nutrition.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now

His blood pressure is unstable, requiring pressors, and his heart rate is elevated at 107 bpm. The patient also has acute renal failure with a rising creatinine level.

The patient has been receiving piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) for antibiotics, pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and midodrine/octreotide for hepatorenal syndrome. He is also receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) without lipids.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt
   - Continue Midodrine per hepatology recs
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now, but could consider if patient begins
   having increased bowel sounds to help increase gastric motility and
   improve abdominal distension
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - holding on repeat paracentesis as will not alter clinical management
   at this time
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Maintain on ventilator; transitioning pt to PSV today ([**12-22**]). Will
   titrate as tolerated.
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 1-1.5L out
   - PM lytes
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved
   UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - daily IV albumin 50g IV daily
   - monitor UOP closely
   - check urine lytes
   - decreased dose of Octreotide by
 for HRS dosing
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 1-1.5L out
   - PM lytes
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes.
   Initiate TPN today and consult nutrition.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line

   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis and a possible case of pneumonia. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure of 135/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is intubated and on PSV ventilation. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, as well as elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. The patient has metabolic acidosis and altered mental status. Imaging reveals increased diffuse left lung opacity and increased blunting of the left costophrenic angle, consistent with fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's dyspnea and hypotension suggest the possibility of respiratory failure. The patient is already intubated and on mechanical ventilation, but there may be a need for further respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated white blood cell count indicate potential sepsis. He has been diagnosed with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and may have concurrent pneumonia.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis and possibly CAP. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), chronic anemia, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis, metabolic acidosis, and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised, as indicated by the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation. There is a concern for pneumonia or influenza, and the presence of fluid overload and congestive heart failure (CHF) may contribute to his respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: The patient shows signs of systemic infection, which can lead to sepsis. His elevated white blood cell count, fever, and tachycardia are indicative of an infection.
3. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The patient has symptoms consistent with SBP, including abdominal pain, elevated neutrophil count in ascitic fluid, and significant left shift on CBC with diff. SBP is a life-threatening complication of cirrhosis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   - Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda 12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc,
   Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt and Midodrine per hepatology recs
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now, but could consider if patient begins
   having increased bowel sounds to help increase gastric motility and
   improve abdominal distension
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - holding on repeat paracentesis as will not alter clinical management
   at this time
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Maintain on ventilator; transitioning pt to PSV today ([**12-22**]).
   Attempt to decrease PEEP from 15 -> 12
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 1-1.5L out
   - PM lytes
   .
   Leukocytosis:  Most likely etiology is C. diff given antibiotics and
   leukocytosis with low grade fever.  No clear evidence of infection.
   - f/u C. diff
   - Consider pan culture if develops fever or leukocytosis worsens
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome, given patient has received free water yesterday without
   sodium response.
   - D5W 2L today
   - Consider free water flushes if hypernatremia fails to improve, but
   hold for now
   - Lasix 40mg IV x1
   - Spironolactone 100mg daily to diurese sodium off
   - Goal I/O -1.5-2L today
   .
   Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen,
   but marked tenderness of areolar region b/l is concerning.
   - Consult liver regarding tenderness, and whether this occurs with
   gynecomastia
   - Prolactin level
   - Discuss with GF whether pt had tenderness at baseline, as pt has been
   non-responsive until recently
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved
   UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - daily IV albumin 50g IV daily
   - monitor UOP closely
   - check urine lytes
   - decreased dose of Octreotide by
 for HRS dosing
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 1-1.5L out
   - PM lytes
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes.
   Initiate TPN today and consult nutrition.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He presented with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis, possibility of CAP, and sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a recent transition to pressure support ventilation (PSV) mode. He has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute on chronic liver failure, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), thrombocytopenia, anemia, altered mental status, and hepatitis C cirrhosis. The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including volume overload, fluid imbalance, electrolyte disturbances, renal dysfunction, gastrointestinal bleeding, coagulopathy, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, influenza, ascites, or congestive heart failure (CHF). Maintaining the patient on mechanical ventilation and gradually decreasing PEEP may help improve oxygenation.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has deteriorated, indicated by rising creatinine levels. Hepatorenal syndrome and aggressive diuresis are possible causes. Daily monitoring of urine output, electrolyte balance, and consideration of renal replacement therapy may be necessary.

   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved
   UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - daily IV albumin 50g IV daily
   - monitor UOP closely
   - check urine lytes
   - decreased dose of Octreotide by
 for HRS dosing
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 1-1.5L out
   - PM lytes
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes.
   Initiate TPN today and consult nutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis presenting with peritonitis caused by Clostridium perfringens. The patient is currently experiencing septic shock and respiratory failure. 

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 126/56 mmHg to 165/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's CVP is at 20 mmHg, indicating adequate fluid status. 

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP at 15 cmH2O. ABG results indicate a pH of 7.49, PaCO2 of 42 mmHg, PaO2 of 220, and HCO3- of 32 mEq/L, suggesting a respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis. 

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 16.4 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 46 K/uL. Other lab values such as glucose, electrolytes, liver function tests, and coagulation profiles are also provided. 

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, intubation, sedation, normal

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   - Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda 12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc,
   Clindamycin, Micafungin; = continue cipro/clinda
   - Continue Octreotide gtt and Midodrine per hepatology recs
   - rising WBC: blood culture if spikes (even low spike); sputum culture
   now; c.diff send repeat
   - diagnostic para today
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia, as concern for
   infection
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - diagnostic paracentesis today
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Continue on PSV with current PEEP of 10 today, as tolerated
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - cultures today
   - diurese today with lasix 80mg, goal 1-1.5L negative
   - 5pm lytes
   - 100mg daily spironolactone continue
   .
   Leukocytosis:  Most likely etiology is C. diff given antibiotics and
   leukocytosis with low grade fever.  No clear evidence of infection.
   - pan-culture, repeat c.diff
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome.
   - Give another 1 L of D5W at 150cc/hour
    - pm lyte check
   - Cont. free water flushes
   - diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone
   .
   Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen,
   but marked tenderness of areolar region b/l is concerning. Prolactin
   elevated.
   - cont tamoxifen
   - discuss with GF whether pt had tenderness at baseline, as pt has been
   non-responsive until recently
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - continue octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Improved.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea, diffuse abdominal pain, and found to have peritonitis and a possible CAP. The patient's condition is complicated by sepsis, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (AKI), hypernatremia, gynecomastia, altered mental status, anemia, hepatitis C cirrhosis, and thrombocytopenia. The patient has been treated with various medications and interventions, including antibiotics, diuretics, vasopressors, and blood transfusions. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 117/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on supplemental oxygen.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's presentation with fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated white blood cell count suggests sepsis. The source of infection could be spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) or pneumonia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's dyspnea and low oxygen saturation indicate respiratory failure. The underlying cause could be pneumonia, aspiration, or fluid overload due to cirrhosis.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with

   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].

ed Vanc,
   Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue Octreotide gtt and Midodrine per hepatology recs
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.

   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now, but could consider if patient begins

   improve abdominal distension
   - f/u GI/Liver recs

   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - holding on repeat paracentesis as will not alter clinical management
   at this time
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.

   - Consider pan culture if develops fever or leukocytosis worsens
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome, given patient has received free water yesterday without
   sodium response.
   - D5W 2L today
   - Cont. free water flushes
   - Lasix 40mg IV x1

s creatinine has been rising again x

The patient's current conditions include septic shock, respiratory failure, hypernatremia, acute pain, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), chronic anemia, acute anemia secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding), chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, hepatitis, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.3°C (99.2°F), heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 125/63 mmHg to 139/72 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is not mentioned.

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. The respiratory support indicates the need for careful monitoring and management of the patient's ventilation parameters.

The patient has a history of chronic liver disease, as evidenced by cirrhosis and previous episodes of SBP. These conditions increase the risk of complications such as hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and renal dysfunction.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21, and pt was
   transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   - Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda 12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc,
   Clindamycin, Micafungin; = continue cipro/clinda
   - Continue Octreotide gtt and Midodrine per hepatology recs
   - rising WBC: blood culture if spikes (even low spike); sputum culture
   now; c.diff send repeat
   - diagnostic para today
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia, as concern for
   infection
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - diagnostic paracentesis today
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Continue on PSV with current PEEP of 10 today, as tolerated
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - cultures today
   - diurese today with lasix 80mg, goal 1-1.5L negative
   - 5pm lytes
   - 100mg daily spironolactone continue
   .
   Leukocytosis:  Most likely etiology is C. diff given antibiotics and
   leukocytosis with low grade fever.  No clear evidence of infection.
   - pan-culture, repeat c.diff
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome.
   - Give another 1 L of D5W at 150cc/hour
    - pm lyte check
   - Cont. free water flushes
   - diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone
   .
   Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen,
   but marked tenderness of areolar region b/l is concerning. Prolactin
   elevated.
   - cont tamoxifen
   - discuss with GF whether pt had tenderness at baseline, as pt has been
   non-responsive until recently
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - continue octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Improved.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   - culture of infection
   - telemetry
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: D5W today, replete electrolytes.  TPN.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient's medical complications and conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possibly pneumonia. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluid resuscitation.

2. SBP: The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest SBP, which is an infection of the ascitic fluid. It is a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment with antibiotics.

3. Pneumonia: The patient has symptoms consistent with pneumonia, including fever, elevated white blood cell count, and a possible infiltrate on chest X-ray. Appropriate antibiotics are being administered.

4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has deteriorated during hospitalization, likely due to aggressive diuresis and IV contrast exposure. Hepatorenal syndrome is also a consideration.

5. Altered Mental Status: The patient exhibits decreased mental status, which could be attributed to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy, especially given the patient's severe liver disease and rising bilirubin levels.

6. Anemia: The patient has a chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer.

7. Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis, evidenced by a MELD score of 27 and elevated bilirubin levels.

8.

   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   - Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda 12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc,
   Clindamycin, Micafungin; = continue cipro/clinda for now
   - Peritoneal infection appears adequately treated, given recent para
   with WBC 86 (<250).
   - Leukocytosis: Unclear source at present
sputum, blood, urine cultures
   are pending. C. diff has been negative x 2.  As pt has been clinically
   improving over same period, will continue to monitor and keep only
   Cipro/Clinda for now.
   - Broaden abx if pt spikes a fever or decompensate (add back
   Vanc/Zosyn).
   - Discontinuing Octreotide gtt per hepatology recs
   - Continuing Midodrine
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - will try to discontinue lines, as patient improves clinically.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - results of recent paracentesis do not suggest on-going intraabdominal
   infection.
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Continue on PSV with current PEEP of 10 today, as tolerated
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off since [**12-19**]
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 0.5-1L negative today
   - 5pm lytes
   - continue 100mg daily spironolactone
   - will check an SBT with ABG before and after
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome. Currently resolved.
   - Will continue free water flushes at 300cc q6h.
    - pm electrolyte check
   -  diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone.
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Improved.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, additional AMS w/u if no improvement with tx of
   hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures
   - Checking direct bilirubin today ([**12-25**]), as pt w. decr HCT and
   increased total bili, to rule out hemolysis.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   - culture of infection
   - telemetry
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   . Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen.
   Prolactin elevated. Pt has a history of painful gynecomastia, per pt
   girlfriend.
   - cont tamoxifen
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - d/c octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: D5W today, replete electrolytes.  TPN.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, SQH
   Access: R triple-lumen IJ, a-line

He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and was found to have peritonitis as well as a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).
